contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Picture of Frank Damrosch.jpg|thumb|Picture of Frank Damrosch, by Davis & Sanford]] '''Frank Heino Damrosch''' (June 22, 1859 – October 22, 1937) was a German-born American music conductor and educator. ==Life and career== Damrosch was born on June 22, 1859 in [[Breslau]], the son of Helene von Heimburg, a former opera singer, and conductor [[Leopold Damrosch]]. He came to the United States with his father, brother, conductor [[Walter Damrosch]], and sister, music teacher [[Clara Mannes]], in 1871. His parents were Lutheran (his paternal grandfather was Jewish).<ref>[http://books.google.ca/books?id=fbQiAAAAMAAJ&q=Helene+von+Heimburg++lutheran&dq=Helene+von+Heimburg++lutheran&hl=en]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.ca/books?id=4fgJawIYjHwC&pg=PR9&dq=Leopold+Damrosch+lutheran&hl=en]</ref><ref>[http://books.google.ca/books?id=rVLOhGt1BX0C&pg=RA1-PA490&dq=%22pianist+and+music+educator,+was+born+in+Breslau%22&hl=en&redir_esc=y]</ref> He had studied music in Germany under [[Dionys Pruckner]]. He studied in New York under [[Ferdinand von Inten]]. He also studied in Europe under [[Moritz Moszkowski]]. He originally intended to adopt a business career, and to that end went to [[Denver, Colorado]], but the musical impulse proved too strong, and in 1884 he was an organist, conductor of the [[Denver Chorus Club]], and supervisor of music in the [[Public education|public schools]]. For some years he was chorus master at the [[Metropolitan Opera|Metropolitan Opera House]] in New York. He also conducted the [[Mendelssohn Glee Club]] from 1885 to 1887. In 1892 he organized the People's Singing Classes, and he was also instrumental in founding the [[Musical Art Society of New York]]. In 1897 he became supervisor of music in the public schools in New York. In 1898 Damrosch succeeded his brother [[Walter Johannes Damrosch|Walter]] as conductor of the [[Oratorio Society of New York|Oratorio Society]], which he directed until 1912. Damrosch Park, part of New York's [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts]], is named in honor of the Damrosch family. In 1905 he founded and became director of the [[New York Institute of Musical Art]]. One of Damrosch's pupils was [[William Howland (musician)|William Howland]], who was head of the music department at the [[University of Michigan]] for many years. In 1926, the Institute of Musical Art merged with the Juilliard Graduate School to form what is today [[Juilliard School]].<ref>http://www.juilliard.edu/about/history.php</ref> Damrosch died in New York City on October 22, 1937.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Founder of Musical Institute and Brother of Walter Is Heart Stroke Victim |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F3061FFD3959177A93C1AB178BD95F438385F9 |quote=Frank Heino Damrosch, founder of the Institute of Musical Art, a member of a great family of musicians and a man who did much for the spread of musical learning in New York, died early yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his home, 120 East Seventy-fifth Street. He was 78 years old. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=October 23, 1937 |accessdate=2010-09-17 }}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} * This article contains text from a work now in the [[public domain]]: {{Cite journal|journal=[[Etude Magazine]]|date=August 1910|url=http://scriabin.com/etude/1910/08/etude-gallery-of-musical-celebrities.html|title=Etude Gallery of Musical Celebrities}} ==External links== {{Commons}} * {{Cite EB1922|Damrosch, Walter Johannes}} {{Authority control|VIAF=11070708|GND=135729513}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Damrosch, Frank | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = United States classical music conductor and educator | DATE OF BIRTH = June 22, 1859 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Breslau]] | DATE OF DEATH = October 22, 1937 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[New York City]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Damrosch, Frank}} [[Category:1859 births]] [[Category:1937 deaths]] [[Category:American conductors (music)]] [[Category:German emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:People from Wrocław]] [[Category:People from the Province of Silesia]]
